key_behaviors: Uses AI weekly for personal tasks
Leverages AI for complex health research and quick, well‑sourced answers
Uses AI to plan outings (hikes, trips) by gathering options, distances, and nearby amenities
Employs AI for writing assistance – improving drafts, generating ideas, or creating text from scratch
Copies AI‑generated summaries or option lists into messages for friends
Cherry‑picks useful phrases from AI output and then edits to retain personal voice
pain_points: AI writing assistance sometimes produces output that feels inauthentic or not aligned with personal voice
Dissatisfaction with AI output may stem from poor prompting or limited contextual understanding
Lack of transparent sourcing and quality‑assurance makes it hard to trust AI for important decisions
Uncertainty about how to verify AI‑provided sources without spending extra time
Reluctance to integrate AI with personal systems (calendar, email) due to privacy or control concerns
trust_factors: High overall trust rating (4/5) despite concerns
Desire for well‑sourced answers that can be independently verified
Preference for a human‑in‑the‑loop or other vetting mechanism to guard against over‑trust
Confidence grows when AI delivers fast, accurate summaries that match manual research
desires: An assistant that handles disliked tasks (research, planning) without sacrificing accuracy
Built‑in quality assurance, possibly with human review, to ensure trustworthiness
Clear citation of sources so the user can quickly assess credibility
Ability to preserve the user’s personal voice while offering concise phrasing options
Optional, controlled integration with calendars or email only if it adds clear value

verbatim_quotes.quote: I use AI tools sometimes for tasks that require more complex research. These are things that would take me a longer time to research on my own. For example, if I have a health-related question, I want an answer that considers multiple sources of research or a quick but well-researched answer to something like that, such as a health question or how to handle a specific situation.
I've also used it for planning, like finding options for a local hike or outing, factoring in distance, nearby restaurants or coffee shops, and the length of the hike.
It does so in a much faster amount of time and presents it back in a great summary format.

When I use AI for trip planning, I was strapped for time while trying to meet up with a friend for an afternoon. I kind of knew what we wanted but didn't have a lot of time to research it. I also wanted to share options with her. So, I did some research and provided a short summary that I could easily copy.
Sometimes when I have to try to use it for writing assistance, I don't really like what I get out of it, and I maybe prefer what I could do by hand.
I think the writing assistance falls short when I'm working on something where one of the highest values is authenticity. I don't want to lose my personal voice in it.

I just cherry-pick the best phrases. If I find something in there that I do like, as far as a phrase, maybe it's more concise than what I did, but still keeps my voice. I'll pull a couple of phrases that I like, but then go back and just kind of re-edit my own thing.
It would be really well-sourced so that it could give me true confidence, which would help build trust.

I've heard that people have started to put a higher amount of trust in AI once they're working with it than is maybe earned or warranted, and I could maybe fall into that same trap. So I think if there were ways it could legitimately ensure trustworthiness, that would be a true value.
I think sourcing is one thing, but it also takes time and requires me to be knowledgeable about the sources. So I'm not really sure.
I'm not sure that I want to connect with those systems.
I thought it had a decent flow to it. I didn't mind it, and it didn't make me hold back or anything.

Well, I think you're missing the human kind of back-and-forth of a natural conversation where you get a head nod, just nonverbal feedback, basically. But I do think that AI was good at acknowledging the last answer and following up in a logical way, so that was good.

unique_insights: The participant reports high overall trust in AI (rating 4/5) yet simultaneously worries about a "trust trap" where over‑reliance could be unjustified. Their primary friction point is not the lack of functionality but the inability of AI to guarantee source credibility and preserve personal voice, leading them to manually cherry‑pick and edit AI output. They are also ambivalent about deep integration with personal productivity tools, preferring optional, controlled connections only if clear benefits are demonstrated.
